Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Nonoperative Treatment and Hemiarthroplasty for Four-Part Proximal Humerus Fractures in the Elderly

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to nonoperative treatment or hemiarthroplasty.

Participants.evidence: 50 patients aged 65 years and older with four-part proximal humerus fractures.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to nonoperative treatment or hemiarthroplasty.

Objective.evidence: This study aims to compare nonoperative treatment and hemiarthroplasty regarding function, strength, and pain.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Constant-Murley score at 12 months.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to treatment allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 50 patients aged 65 years and older with four-part proximal humerus fractures.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis was performed on an intention-to-treat basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The effect size for the primary outcome was [effect size], with a 95% confidence interval of [confidence interval] and a p-value of [p-value].

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
